Section Header:
You are invited to take part in an online survey research study. 

 

This research survey is being conducted by Dr. Andrea Murphy, Dr. David Gardner, Dr. Sherry Stewart, Dr. Niki Kiepek, Dr. Igor Yakovenko, and Mr. Bill Berryman. Dr. Murphy is a faculty member in the College of Pharmacy, School of Nursing, and Department of Psychiatry at Dalhousie University. Dr. Gardner is faculty member in the College of Pharmacy, and Department of Psychiatry at Dalhousie University. Dr. Stewart is a faculty member in the Psychiatry, Psychology and Neuroscience, and Community Health and Epidemiology departments at Dalhousie University. Dr. Kiepek is a faculty member in the School of Occupational Therapy at Dalhousie University. Dr. Yakovenko is a faculty member of the Department of Psychiatry, and Psychology and Neuroscience departments at Dalhousie University. Mr. Berryman is Chair of the Seniors’ Advisory Council of Nova Scotia.

 

The online survey has been made available by Dalhousie University using the research electronic data capture tool called REDCap.

 

The purpose of this survey is to identify factors reported by older adults that are associated with decreasing and stopping sleeping pills. Specifically, we are interested in learning about experiences with sleeping pills that are also called benzodiazepine receptor agonists (BZRAs). The following table shows the medication names of the BZRAs. 

 

Zopiclone

Temazepam

Lorazepam

Oxazepam

Clonazepam

Triazolam

Alprazolam

Zolpidem

Bromazepam

Eszopiclone

Chlordiazepoxide

Flurazepam

Diazepam

Nitrazepam

 

Information gathered by this survey will help the researchers understand people’s perspectives on taking sleeping pills and their experiences when attempting to stop their use. The survey lists several factors thought to be associated with difficulties stopping sleeping pills. You will be asked to rate your level of agreement on statements about these factors. You will be also asked questions related to your personality to see how personality type is related to stopping sleeping pills. The researchers will use the data to improve the safe use of sleeping pills in older adults.

 

This survey is for people:

  • 65 years of age or older 
  • live independently (e.g., do not live in a nursing home or in a long-term care centre)
  • currently taking a sleeping pill or stopped taking a sleeping pill within the past 2 years 

You will be asked questions to verify your eligibility at the start of the survey.

 

In this survey, you will be asked to rate your agreement with statements about your experiences while taking sleeping pills and attempting to stop them. There are also questions about your demographics, health status, and current use of medications for sleep. The survey is expected to take 30 to 50 minutes for you to complete.   

 

We will NOT ask for your name or any personal information that could identify you. This makes your answers anonymous.

 

Your participation in this research is entirely your choice. You are welcome to stop the survey at any time if you no longer want to participate. All you need to do is close your internet browser page. You will not be able to change your mind about participating in the survey after you complete it. This is because we will not be able to identify your responses from the other participants.  

 

Only the lead researcher, Dr. Andrea Murphy, and the co-investigators, Dr. David Gardner and Dr. Igor Yakovenko will have access to the survey results. 

 

When this research study is complete, the main findings will be shared publicly at the sleepstudy.ca website. The results will also be shared with health care professionals through conference presentations and professional publications. Dr. Murphy will keep the anonymous survey information for 6 years, after which it will be securely destroyed. 

 

The risks associated with participating in this study are considered low. Some people may reflect on their sleeping pill use from completing the survey and, if so, are encouraged to speak with their health care provider (i.e., prescriber, pharmacist). There is no expected benefit to you from participating in this research.   

 

You should discuss any questions you have about this study through the dedicated email for this study sleepingpillsurvey@dal.ca and Dr. Murphy will respond to you. Alternatively, you can phone 1-844-929-6762.

 

If you have any ethical concerns about your participation in this research, you may contact Research Ethics, Dalhousie University at (902) 494-3423, or email ethics@dal.ca (and reference REB file # 2020-5201).”
